number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												Personal review of: S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear SkyMods: S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky CompleteDifficulty: MasterS.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky is a sequel/prequel to the events prior to Shadow of Chernobyl. Taking place in 2011, where a second emission took place and created the Zone, a place filled with mutants, strange anomalies, and it's populated by STALKERS, basically scavengers/fighters/artifact seekers, you get the point. You play as Scar, a veteran STALKER chasing down Strelok when an emission hits and you are left incapacitated. You wake up at Clear Sky base, a swamp base where this faction is devoted to understanding the Zone and learning all it's secrets and uncovering the strange phenomens going on. After you finish a few tasks you are free to explore the Zone and side with whatever faction you want, explore and play the game. I won't say more than this since it took me 2,5 hours just to leave the Swamp areas (doing quests, exploring etc.), so the rest is up to you to find out. The game is built on the same X-Ray engine, with a few updated changes. Mainly the AI has been tweeked to fit the new faction war system, visuals have been upped, and many more changes have been implemented. As far as Stalker Clear Sky goes, almost all the weapons have been reused for this prequel, half of the areas too meaning you will revisit some familiar places while exploring new ones. Enemies, NPC's too, so you might find the actual content of this one a bit lacking. Onto more relevant changes, the HUD got reworked, being simplified, also the PDA got some new features, being able to track more easily your tasks, you can now see enemy/friendly factions on the radar, giving you a better understading of where they are being concentrated, etc. The hunger system has been removed, don't know why honestly, weapon upgrades are available, the way you collect/obtain artifacts has also been changed, to the point where you need to use an artifact detector to "see" them. This also implies you will have to walk into the middle of anomalies and hope you won't get killed before you collect them. Stalker Clear Sky has received some flak, being the "weakest" part of the trilogy, and I can see why. This game really kicks you in the balls, same as Shadow of Chernobyl, you start off really underpowered, with little to no ammo/supplies to push through the onslaught of enemies in the Swamp areas. Beware, playing this game and rushing the main storyline will result in a frustratingly hard game. I recommend taking your time and exploring, doing side-quests, parting with different factions as it will result in a much more relaxed experience. It's hard as ♥♥♥♥. There's no doubt about it. But why is it hard? All Stalker games are hard, there's no question about it, this is how these games were built, as an PC exclusive hardcore survival/rpg-ish experience, but S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky comes short in some areas. The thing is the atmosphere, lighting, texture quality is on par and beyond it's first game, but it falls flat in AI behaviour, there are less underground areas to explore (which were a highlight), side tasks include a lot of fetching and killing. These are the most basic things about it. Then we move into combat, wich remains largely unchanged except for one thing. Grenades, I can't stres enough how annoying this addition is, not only will NPC's hit you 90% with them, they will also result in an instant death on higher difficutly levels, which is not very Stalker like. We all know how you can't really take cover in these games, being surrounded by anomalies, high radiation levels and NPC's throwing grenades makes the combat feel unfair at times. Also the fact that they still use the same weapons as you use, only with 100% accuracy and 0 bullet drop is just horse♥♥♥♥♥♥ Seriously. My main gripe with this game is the combat. It feels so random and so luck based that it's the single thing that really kills this game. Don't get me wrong, this is a massive game, with tons of stuf to do, but when it comes to combat (being an FPS game also) it sucks. It just ♥♥♥♥ing sucks. Bullets dance around hitboxes all the time, it feels like when you shoot in S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky you play roullete or you roll the dice. It all comes down to what the game wants to hit, not you. Fully upgraded weapons feel the same, so there's no excuse here. Secondly, the last part of the game (Once you reach Limansk) is just A grade bullcrap. This whole area is designed around enemies placed in hard to reach/predict areas, Monolith soldiers are so buffed, I died almost 50 times in the last part of the game alone. Seriously, a fully upgraded suit will only serve to protect you against 2-3 bullets maximum. There are also a lot of engine crashes here and plenty of bugs, so expect to be disappointed near the end of the game. And now, we have to move to the Chernobyl NPP area. SPOILER ALERT Once you reach Chernobly, this is where the game was at it's worst. First off, there are so many enemies at once, it's likely you will die 90% of the time without any chance of shooting back. Why? They never miss, they take 10-15 bullets to get killed. Also you're presured by the fac that you have to hit Strelok with a gun that isn't effective at all against all the Monolith soldiers being spawned  in this area. This last level is probably one of the worst I've ever played. No joke, hitscan enemies everywhere, almost 0 cover and little or no indication to what you're supposed to do or where Strelok is, I'm not asking for a ♥♥♥♥ing bullseye above his head, but seriously the minimap is useless here, and so are the teleporters, serving only to confuse the player. Want to know how♥♥♥♥♥♥this level is? It took me one hour to finish it, only because I died constantly and 70% of the time I was loading my last save game. When I did finish it, Strelok got stuck in an area off screen, seriously, he was outside Chernobyl and I was able to snipe him only to get the ending which only disappointed me. I played SoC and CoP and those game featured multiple endings, to my delight, here it's just the same 30 seconds cutscene, which I won't discuss for the sake of your own discovery. Anyways, let's cut the crap since this game is from 2008 and I've talked so much already nobody is going to bother reading this anyway, so here is a small list of what works and what doesn't in the 2nd Stalker instalmentThe good:Superb atmosphereAmazing lighting effectsAstounding weather changes + the seamless shifts from day-nightFaction warsWeapon customizationImproved HUD + PDA/Map systemRefined visuals, better draw distance and richer enviromentsHuge sandboxThe bad:Recycled enemies, weapons, enviroments make this Prequel feel like they used cut content/turned a boxed expansion pack into a standalone titleHorrible gun mechanics, play it for yourself I can't explain it (note: I didn't play the vanilla version, I can't imagine how bad the guns perform in the base game)The beginning and ending of this game are atrocious. HonestlyFewer underground areas, which were a highlight of this seriesThey removed the hunger system, the stamina system sucks in this, making it feel less survival compared to SoC and CoPLack of impact on the overall arch of the story, no matter what faction you chose, it all boils down to what gear you obtain, rendering the whole "choice" of it all utterly useless.Less russian dialogue and voiced lines, rendering the immersion to a bare minimum in this title.Little to non-existent expansion on the Stalker universe&lore.In the end, I can only recommend S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky only with Mods, I've tried it with Complete only, but I still recommend it, there are few games that come close to it. A personal rating of 7/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												"S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Clear Sky" - ReviewGameplay:  6/10This second installment "Clear sky" leaves something to be desired. Some elements were indeed improved upon such as weapons: dynamics, upgrade-ability and inaccuracy. The use of image blurring also added more depth. This certainly made the game much more fun. A slightly larger world (even though some of it is lifted straight out of the first game) was just what it needed.These things worked well.They've taken the game to an exciting new level by going deeper into the RPG genre (e.g. goods trading etc) which unfortunately has come at the expense of the 'first person shooter' gameplay, and the game suffers for it. It's no-longer balanced; it simply doesn't flow as well as it's predecessor. Going from story to action feels like segments of contrived scenarios of RPG then FPS then RPG then FPS. Even though things happen in-game and around the map without me being there (living world) overall it leaves me feeling more like I'm being taken for a ride rather than being an integral part that sways the flow and outcome.By half way into the game the shoot outs were predicable and by the end of the game the shooting scenes were frustrating unless you have upgraded armor and guns.Initially it seems like a lesser game than the first one but it gets better the more you play it. It's not a bad game; if you can forgive it's minor short comings it can still be lots and lots of fun.Game ambiance: 7/10Standard S.T.A.L.K.E.R. ambiance which is nice as expected. Leaves, birds, rain, wind and weather. Reliability/Stability: 4/10Installation was easy enough (both DVD and Steam versions) but in-game there quite a few bugs. Some around AI, the faction wars and some were graphics related. Stability hugely varies depending on the PC.Story/Plot: 4/10There were some new ideas expressed which were a lot of fun. However, once you strip away the faction wars and take a good look at the story there's not much there, the overall plot was weak and lacked depth which added to the games segregated feel.While there is a bit of a twist (if you can call it a twist... more like an interesting angle) i don't much care for it. All i can say without giving anything away is that I felt like all my work in the first S.T.A.L.K.E.R. game was done for nothing, and then undone.Concept: 8/10I get the impression that at the beginning of the "clear sky" project the game developers had a good range of ideas, then somewhere along the line they got lost in what can only be described as a quagmire of loose ends and poorly finished tid-bits.Concept execution: 6/10Is should have been a well rounded, a matured concept.Faction wars extend what could have been a short game into an epic one. The novelty of joining factions was fun initially but when it eventually looses it's luster you realise the only motivation for acquiring money in the first place is for weapons. Which is OK, big guns are cool.The AI is a little better but buggy; rather than going around you the AI guys push you out of their way and straight into the line of fire.Textures: 8/10The textures were a great improvement on the first game. There is a warmer feel, they are more sharp and use some more modern features. Although the settings will have to by played with to get optimum results.I love that the PC's in the game use Norton Commander.Modelling: 7/10There really weren't many new elements (most were from the first game). What it does have looks good though.Graphics: 8/10The graphics are a vast improvement; 'Clear sky' does blend each element better than the first game and it certainly added to the overall look and feel. Even though the draw distance could have been greater.That being said, there could have been much more work done in the way of OOP. As on many systems there is a huge draw of resources for graphics that shouldn't require it.Sound: 7/10Sound too was an improvement compared to the first game. Clean, clear, crisp.Music: 5/10The dynamics of the music was good even though the style was not my personal preference, but hey, it's art. There were some song elements that were from the first game and other songs that sound like songs from Mech Warrior: Mercenaries that didn't make the final cut.Adjustable shadow mapping: NoBonus/Extras:Special edition comes with - Novel Book (Russian), Zone map, extras DVD, Instruction manual, bandana, zippo lighter, dog tag, poster, Russian calender circa 1985, random faction badge and a ball that lights up with S.T.A.L.K.E.R. on it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												Universally considered the "worst" STALKER game out of the three, it is not necessarily a bad game. In short, if you like any other STALKER game you should give this a playthrough.This game lacks the bleakness and some of the atmosphere found mainly in Shadow of Chernobyl but also Call of Pripyat. The Zone is very populated by NPCs compared to other STALKER games which very much contributes to the fact that the environment feels less hostile. Compared to the 4 horror centric underground areas of SHoC, Clear Sky only has one that is less frightening compared to the SHoC counterparts. Compared to unmodded SHoC, Clear Sky is in many ways a bit more polished in terms of better animation quality, graphical effects and user interface. Clear Sky also introduces a much welcomed weapon upgrade/repair system that was absent from SHoC.While I generally think that the first time you play a STALKER game it should be unmodded I would say that I make an exception for Clear Sky. Clear Sky unmodded has some issues that are flat out annoying and I would consider it bare minimum to install the Sky Reclamation Project (latest version as of 2015-06-30 is 1.0.4) to fix most of those issues. SRP is still pretty close to a vanilla experience and is provided mainly to fix various bugs.I would also like to mention the following mods that doesn't impact gameplay but makes it look a bit better.Atmosfear 1.3 - Improves weather effects, improves game atmosphere (This is also available for Call of Pripyat)Absolute Nature/Structures - High resolution texture mods that makes things look a bit more crisp (This is also available for Shadow of Chernobyl and Call of Pripyat)

												While the weakest game in the line up it is still loads of fun and maintains much of the bleak and beautiful atmosphere of the other games.  The glitches are more noticable and don't blend in as well with rest of the environment like in the first game, but on the whole none of them are game ruining.  Ultimately all of the issues can be smoothed out with community mods, that are abundant to say the least, and can be found in the forums and support pages.  If you are new to the series I don't recomend starting with this game, but it is a must for those who know and enjoyed one of the other two.8/10  re-defined bolt throwing.  Will never leave home without bolts again.

In addition, if you played the other two stalker games and you've began to miss the Zone, get this. even though it's not perfect, it's still Stalker, and the Zone is still that unforgiving nuclear wasteland that you've been craving for so long.

What it does have looks good though.Graphics: 8/10The graphics are a vast improvement; 'Clear sky' does blend each element better than the first game and it certainly added to the overall look and feel. Even though the draw distance could have been greater.That being said, there could have been much more work done in the way of OOP. As on many systems there is a huge draw of resources for graphics that shouldn't require it.Sound: 7/10Sound too was an improvement compared to the first game. Clean, clear, crisp.Music: 5/10The dynamics of the music was good even though the style was not my personal preference, but hey, it's art. There were some song elements that were from the first game and other songs that sound like songs from Mech Warrior: Mercenaries that didn't make the final cut.Adjustable shadow mapping: NoBonus/Extras:Special edition comes with - Novel Book (Russian), Zone map, extras DVD, Instruction manual, bandana, zippo lighter, dog tag, poster, Russian calender circa 1985, random faction badge and a ball that lights up with S.T.A.L.K.E.R. on it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												Oh where do I begin with Clear Sky? For some reason a lot of game journalists hated on this follow-up title, I'm not sure if they expected a more fully fledged sequel, but that doesn't make sense when you look at games like Crysis Warhead which, while improving on the original game in terms of playability, sort of trimmed up the narrative elements for I don't know brevity's sake I suppose. I mean look IGN gave it a full .9 game review units lower than Shadow of Chernobyl. I take that to mean that the game reviewer spent 9% less time playing it? That was a terrible joke.I have started Clear Sky and yes I'm using the COMPLETE modpack that sort of patches the game up more or less, and yes it does seem less buggy than I remember from playing it a few years ago. It's also much more visually impressive; you've got to hand it to GSC they really do work hard on making the game both functionally a living-breathing world, but also a visually impressive and at times terrifying visual spectacle. The story throws you right into the world of "The Zone" much like its predecessor, but unlike its predecessor your character's motivations are much more established in the opening scenes. With the first game it's more of a mystery of your identity that you have to solve (despite the game not ever explicity stating that your identity is unknown to your character). Clear Sky puts you right in the muddy worn-out boots of a STALKER who, while escorting a group of scientists, gets inocculated and then rescued from an event that for some unknown reason, you survived. So there is a mystery of yourself that you have to navigate the world to solve, but it's much less dramatic and much more modest, but that modesty grants you an awesome amount of freedom in the game-world.In Clear Sky, because you're not "The Marked One," your main questline doesn't feel so out of congruence with your doing side quests. For me it always felt weird to deviate from the main questline in Shadow because it felt out of character given the circumstance thrown upon "The marked one." The writing and acting from the NPCs reinforces this weird illusion that despite your in-game days of deviating from what should be an imminent threat, they resume helping as if nothing is wrong. I know there's a certain suspension of disbelief you have to engage it, but it's always nice to see developers navigate around these consequnces through the use of clever narrative devices. Clear Sky presents you with a traditional figure-out-the-game set of quests that do override the open world, but once you finish them (which takes less than two hours) you're free to roam and really do anything you want--including working with and eventually joining factions.I'm done talking about this game for now because I want to play it. I'm not done beating it (again) and will finish my thoughts once I've dumped a few more hours into it.Yes I think it's better than Shadow of Chernobyl.ADDENDUM: Actually it is worse than Shadow of Chernobyl. I have decided this based on my last few hours playing and (sort of) beating the game. It just really loses a lot of steam, and the flaws inherent in the combat mechanics render the final quest line push nearly impossible to play. For one thing, the faction war, while intriguing, is really funky. Sometimes your squads never show up to reinforce your position, making your faction's advance toward the enemy base totally stalled--meaning you can't actually beat this portion of the game. There really isn't any good incentive to do this anyway, but completionists will have their knickers in a twist upon realizing that sometimes the faction-war system just breaks. This is big problem with the game. Combat mechanics are similar to SoC, but enemies will have no trouble noticing and then shooting your face from 100 yards off within a matter of like 3 seconds. It is too difficult, and also highly inconsistent with how the combat appears. Sometimes you'll crouch and hunch behind a piece of cover, completely obscuring your view of the enemy shooter, only to have him still shoot you through a tiny gap in the cover, or what I can only assume is a small visible portion of your head that they can see. This makes the game infuriating at times. The ending is so thrown together and terrible, that I'm surprised I was able to complete it without totally cheating. I mean at one part you have to fight through like 25 Monolith stalkers by yourself, your squad leaving you behind for no apparent reason either. I just used the wish granter and spawned a few friendlies to make that encounter not totally terrible. It was still a challenge just not a stupid hard one.It's cool chasing and fighting Strelok at the end, and the implications of the ending are spelled out in the original title. therefore the game lacks any alternate endings, as well as any real tangible consequences with respect to the faction-war. The narrative comes off as dry and very one-tracked, and you're just waiting for it to finish so you can install Call of Pripyat and have a good time.The game's world is awesome though, and to its credit it does improve on quite a lot that SoC lacks. Finding anomalies is much more of a challenge, as you have to navigate dangerous obstacles produced by the anomaly, relying on your trusty bolt, scanner, and anti-rad drugs. Weapon customization is really worth it in this game, and decking out an AK that shoots super fast and has no recoil is always a good move. Clear Sky is such a mixed bag, because there is so much wrong with it, despite it's solid roots in the fantastic original, and it's smart improvements on that formula. It's buggy and many of the level design and AI encounters feel really ♥♥♥♥y. If you're looking to get into stalker, I wouldn't feel bad telling you to just skip this one unless you're really curious. Call of Pripyat is just so much better, and feels like a polished complete title. This feels like a really elaborate mod for the original game that never quite made it to a stable release.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												The prequel of the game STALKER Shadow of Chernobyl.   The user starts as a mercenary named Scar who was found by the Clear Sky faction in The Swamps,unconscious ,after the most powerful emission The Zone ever did, near the bodies of some scientists that he was paid to lead. The character is a mercenary but is not part of the faction "Mercenaries" and he was able to survive 2 emissions that affected his nervous system ( this leads to blurry moments during gameplay).The story takes place in The Zone and your task whether you like it or not is to help the Clear Sky faction find out who is messing with The Zone until The Zone turns every living beeing into ashes.   Clear Sky brings new dangerous areas with new quests, a new anomaly called "Space Anomaly", taxi, improvements to the graphics ( like dx10,sun shafts etc ) and gameplay.The user is now able to repair and modify equipment (guns and suits) with the help of data found on usb sticks ( the mechanics will ask for these for advanced changes) and join factions after helping them defeat their rivals but beware you are neutral to all {except monolith and some mercenaries} and taking part in their wars will set your status "at war" with the faction they're at war. Artefacts aren't spread all over the map like in SoC and since they're produced by anomalies they can be found only in anomalies,invisible to the naked eye but visible with the help of detectors. Almost every settlement has a taxi that can lead you in places ( not everywhere) if you pay him.  The game opens the path for Stalker Shadow Of Chernobyl but doesn't give new info on The Zone. Personally I recommend playing this as vanilla for a true STALKER experience then you can mod it and enjoy unexplored areas.Pros-Work for artefacs ,money and everything else.-Awesome game-Taxi for fast travel-More than one entry in some areasCons-Game has a good chance to crash at the Deserted Hospital, the Red Forest and Limansk resulting in corrupt saves (saves are lost)-Cheap Swamp quests-No direction whatsoever for quests from mechanics etc.For a true STALKER there are no cons.Good hunting Stalker.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												Sim, Clear Sky beira o 'ruim' e o 'não tão bom quanto o SoC mas bom'. O jogo começa bem, open world como o primeiro, te dando opções pra completar as missões, escolha de facções pra uma faction war q parece interessante. Depois começa a frustração. O jogo se afunila e fica linear como um Call of Duty, matando qualquer tipo de exploração e uma ♥♥♥♥♥da de situações scriptadas. O faction war não funciona: você limpa e captura pontos, mas seus aliados não ocupam o local, e qdo vc sai os inimigos simplesmente voltam. Você então desiste do Faction War e foca na story line. Mesmo na dificuldade Normal, os inimigos conseguem te acertar mesmo q você esteja sem 1% do corpo a mostra - atras de cobertura. Conseguem dar tiros certeiros q tiram metade da sua vida. Pra piorar, sua armadura tem durabilidade e a única forma de consertar é com NPCs, e custa caro e nem sempre você tem acesso a eles, principalmente da metade pra frente do jogo, qdo vira um rollerscoaster. A última fase então é um ♥♥♥♥ fest: tem "tempo limite", inimigos q teleportam na sua frente e atras de você, com screenshake atrapalhando sua mira, e você tendo q correr contra o tempo.Como eu disse, o jogo começa bem e termina horrivel. Ele parece ser superior ao SoC por melhorar algumas coisas, como gunplay e facções q realmente fazem a diferença, mas nope, é tudo muito raso. Os gráficos e a ambientação são lindos. Mas é isso. Vale a pena se você tiver muita paciencia, curtir a série e visitar a Zona um pouco diferente.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												Essential things to make the game playable:-Accuracy mod: remove RNG accuracy.-Antialiasing on DX10 and above set to 2x or downsample on your own; use SGSSAA on DX9 or an injection--SMAA (SweetFX) forces the game to DX9. So use eFX if you want DX10.-God rays mod: it makes the game look awesome (and it didn't affect performance in my case). Also, don't install Shaders max mod; it has a lot of compatiblity issues and it affects the performance negatively instead (as the mod author states that it affected half of the users).Warning: I somehow like the game, but I am on the negative side. I am done with it at this point. I do enjoy obsecure games with meh gameplay, provided that they have other redeeming qualities, but gunplay in this game is simply bad.Pros: -Good atmosphere.-Nice graphics.-Great gameplay/survival elements.-Factions and collecting artifacts.Cons:-Extremely bad gameplay.-Badly optimized.-Hypersensitive when it comes to modding.Summary: Don't waste your time with this outdated, dysfunctional piece of crap. If you want to play it, install mods BEFOREHAND and WASTE a large amount of time. I really liked it at first and liked its aesthetics; I am simply disgusted at the fact that I wasted over 5 hours trying to get the damn game to work after installing a couple of mods, and trying to deal with the shooting mechanics. I am 10+ hours into the game and I will not restart just to install a mod that is essential to play the weakest entry in the series.I will start with the most important thing in  video games: gameplay and how functional it is. Clear Sky is not only the weakest entry in the series (supposedly lacking in atmosphere but it is my first Stalker game), but it is utterly unplayable (once you start fighting things and shotguns miss at point blank range) and makes you wonder if the developers/game designers have been exposed to an excessive amount of radiation to even THINK of such game mechanics--the stupid RNG accuracy.First and foremost, shots are based on RNG, which means you will miss 30ft shots and have to waste a magazine at least to land a SHOT; enemies have a huge amount of HP and they have absurd accuracy and aggro mechanics. I am obviously talking about the hardest difficulty in the game, but shooting is dysfunctional either way; the game is simply boring on lower difficulties. Also weapon jamming (RNGesus), bad maps/no cover when you attack a base, stealth doesn't work properly, FRIGGIN SWAY THAT LASTS HALF A SECOND WHEN YOU MOVE AND AIM, slow aim, slow weapon switching, slow reload...etc. The combat is ****.  With that said, you HAVE to install mods in order to have fun on normal difficulties or something functional on the highest difficulties, which brings us to how crappy is the game when it comes to modding. You will spend hours just troubleshooting and figuring out in the end that there is some shader incompatibilty or some crappy dll file missing. And the worst of all is having to restart a new game when you install an overhaul or other types of mods. Another point is the optimization and lack of a proper Antialiasing. The latter completely destroys the performance when you max out the game on DX10.1. I ended up with a much better game that runs on high frame rate and looks good with godrays  mod, but jaggies and transparent object edges are there; 2x is the most subtle option. Trying to use SMAA or FXAA injections means you have to use DX9, so good luck making a decision there. The good point is that the game does feel and look atmospheric, but the combat is an utter piece of crap. The best course of action is to play CoP or SoC (if you can bear with wasting time trying to mod that crap).

content:
Posted: December 10, 2012
												The lowest quality of all of the stalkers. The game is clearly influenced heavily by call of duty, which was released just before this. The vanilla game crashes a lot, enemies are quite powerful and grenade spam is common. Bugs are extremely common, and the level design is quite poor.Some of the freedom of approach is deliberately limited for no reason. For example, in one instance a machine gunner is immune to bullets until you can get behind him and shoot him, even if you have a sniper rifle and can already hit him in the head.Most of the changes to gameplay are negative, and you will be spending most of the time desperately managing your bleeding.However, it does add a lot more to the story than call of pripyat.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2012
												The second installment in the franchise, this is actually a prequel to the original. It was heavily criticized for excessive recycling of maps from the first game, but it makes excellent and different use of them while also adding a lot of new areas. This episode features an earlier version of the weapon upgrade system and item repair and has an elaborate faction system where the player can get involced with, and gain varfied rewards from, struggles between opposing groups.Out of the three game I think this is the best. It has most of the refinemenrts not found in the original while keeping the steady power progression and detail not found in the last chapter.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												Very similar to STALKER ShoC (Shadow of Chernobyl). The only differences I can notice (besides internal game mechanics here and there) is that the Clear Sky is a bit bigger from what I've noticed and that this game is longer than ShoC. I have not beat ShoC but in the time I got to say the city that was located at 75% story in Clear Sky, it took me a much shorter time to reach in ShoC. I dont know if there is a magestic throw back in ShoC like the one in Clear Sky that scared the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of me but other than that Clear Sky is great! I use this game to break my friends into stalker because in my opinion the others are harder, and have better mods. This game is open world, has grid like inventory where say a pistol takes a 1x3 slot and an ak takes say a 2x5 slot and you also have to watch weight encumbrance. There is a nice balance between scavenging, dodging anomalies, hiding from  blowouts, and fighting. I would say that the AI get a debuff here, and a buff there. Sometimes the AI no scopes you, sometimes they miss by a bit (which is good!). I hate how the AI scoots you out of the way. Nothing game breaking was spotted, just bugs here and there. This is most definately bolt-throwing simulator 2014 and auto-saving simulator 2014. Why 2014? I wrote this in 2014.I recommend it, worth full price but I always get games on sale:)

content:

												I finished this game a while back and thought a while about how I'd write my review of it.  I ended up waiting until I was done with CoP before doing it and really there isn't much more to be said about CS or CoP that I didn't say in my SoC review.  These games are fantastic.I've never played more atmospheric games than this series.  The story-telling is also similarly great.  CS takes you back before SoC and gives you a TON of backstory on why and how the events in SoC came to be.  GSC didn't change much of the gameplay elements for CS, which was genius because why ruin a good thing?The S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games are all great and should be experienced together.  They are great on their own but so much better when you've played them all.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2016
												Second Stalker was improved compared with first under many aspects, everything seems to works very well here and much better, but you'll face again an high difficulty, altough a bit lower compared with the first chapter (and this is a positive note for me).Now, you CAN repair your gears, weapons and armors, this was much more than a simple change, this was awesome, believe me :)Altough in the first game thre was the chance to upgrade some gears, in this game this feature is taken to high levels, allowing you to improve a lot your armaments, making you almost invincible, money and schematics allowing, yes, because you'll have first find the proper schematic and take them to the right technician who will be able then to upgrade your stuff....I said above you ned a lot of money to upgrade your gears, so farming money will be very important in this game and will recquire a lot of time and here comes a very negative aspect of this game, because there will be a point in the game, where you'll lose all your money, and no, there is nothing you can do to avoid it, it's part of main story, so my suggestion id to store all your found gears in a stash and sell to vendors only AFTER this disgraceful event will happens.I really hated this feature invented by devs cause there is nothing that advice you before, i spent hours farming and lost all, lucikly a previous savegame fixed in part the problem but made me losea lot of time and patience...And again, another very bad new feature in this game will be the EMISSIONS, a sort of radiation explosion that will happens suddenly while you'll play, no matter where you are and what are you doing (and how much heavy you'll be in that moment, so you'll not be able to run :(  ) so to avoid to be instant killed you'll have to take cover, but, you think that will be enough enter in ahoude or inside a solid tunnel ? Nope, you''ll have to run in specific marked in the map zones (yellow color) where you'll be immune, even if is a n open place, no matter, you'll survive, while you'll die in any other place....So, this could have been a nice feature, if was implemented a little better, but when this random event will happens, you'll be often, ( specially the first time, when you'll die a dozen of times before you'll realize what is happening to you ^^) too damn much far away from the suggested cover point and could happens that you'll not do in time to reeach the safe spot, or because you carry too much stuff that will deny you to run or because in the cover point there are enemies that will kill you while you try to enter, so, with time, you'll learn few tricks that will save your life but, overall, this is very very annoying mini event :(A nice tip, since to make money you'll have to sell weapons dropped by dead soldiers, you'll most of the time be unable to carry more than a few of them cause of the weight limit, making the process difficult cause of the distance to the vendors, i've discovered this after i was already playing and i was very happy of that, dead bodies, of both soldiers and mutants, can be dragged keeping pushed together your USE button + Left SHIFT, this way you can use the corpses like a bag where you can put anyhing you want , altough dragging these corpses for miles could be tricky cause they will fall down from your hands often in the process, you'll have some benefit from this.A new feature of this game is the Factions War, you'll be free if to help some of them and exterminate another or remain neutral with all, you'll receive some serious benefits (in gears) if you'll decide to join some of them, specially The Duty and The Freedom.The search of manufacts, items that will improve some of your stas, incresed of importance here and became a little more funny and pleasant the system to find them.In conclusion, i could recommend this game even to non hardcore players, but the difficulty remain at high levels altough more reasonable compared with the first game.My Final Score is 74 /100

content:
Posted: February 22, 2013
												By far the weakest of the STALKER. games, Clear Sky is still a solid FPS/RPG hybrid, with suprisingly intelligent AI (and surprisingly inconsistent too), which makes for some great firefights.  And I hope you like firefights, because with this game's focus on factions of human NPCs, rather than the mutants, radiation, psychology horror, and physics bending anomalies of Shadow of Chernobyl, you'll do a lot of man-shooting.Definitely a different take on the STALKER experience, and far from a failure, it still lacks the amazingly alien atmosphere of desolate loneliness and creeping fear of the first game. Luckily it was followed up by another entry, which combined the best elements of its predecessors...

content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												Due to some flooding and my terrible internet, I ended up playing this game in offline mode. It's an okay game, but a decent entry into the series. This game is a prequel to Shadow of Cernobyl. Clear Sky contains the entirety of Shadow of Chernobyl's map, with two new zones included; however, this makes playing the game seem like more of an expansion than a standalone title. Clear Sky lacks the pacing that was present in the first title. Within 10 minutes you're loaded up with a pistol, assault rifle, ammo, and medkits. Compared to Shadow of Chernobyl, this game is a lot more action oriented. I finished the campaign with about 650 Stalker/Military/Faction kills, and 100 mutant kills. With so many kills, the gameplay began to feel a bit stale. My favorite part about Clear Sky was seeing how my actions affected the future game. I recommend playing Shadow of Chernobyl first, and following up with this game for the backstory. Overall, I would suggest you skip this title unless you are a big fan of the series; although, I highly recommend the first game.

content:
Posted: January 16
												Just like our first title in the series, this takes you BACK to the zone once again but from a diffrent perspective of sorts. This is a prequel to S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Shadow of Chernobyl story wise but is changed and upgraded gameplay wise. Instead of being "The Marked One" you are now a mercenary named Scar, who is on his mission to chase down and find Strelok. SOUND the same as something before?? You would be right! With a whole new type of battle/gameplay mechanics added in this game might seem to be a challenge to people who have played Shadow of Chernobyl, adapting to the new gameplay style, or for people who are starting the series with this one! Clear Sky for sure packs a punch right back at you from the beginning and I think it is a great game to provide the backstory behind everything to get you ready for the third installment of the game! Totally recommend the normal (Stalker) difficulty for the first run of the game especially if your new to the series and if you are coming here from SoC don't worry.....The pieces all add up soon :) 100% recommend to buy this game to continue the series!

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Awesome game! I have installed "Complete mod" and the landscapes are just brilliant. I was playing a lot Fallout series and comparing to it, Stalker is REAL survivor game - in this game you can't even jump few times in a row, you need to get rest a bit. Duels with enemies are so real that you need to think twice when you attack someone - it's not just about pointing gun at someone and firing, it's very close to real situations. First few times it was hard to adapt to Stalker (as normally I would expect the game to be easy at beginning and then go tricky as you go - but not with Stalker!), as it was particularly harder than Fallout, however after initial learning curve you just can't stop playing it! Definitelly recommended to anyone who likes first-person survial and shooting games.

content:
Posted: February 5
Death by a thousand tiny cutsThis is by far the WORST game in the series. The bugs are unrelenting, and the enemy can effortlessly hit you from any distance with any weapon. When I first started playing this, I thought the factions fighting each other, and the people constantly following objectives was really cool, but as you go through the main story and do more quests, you realize just how braindead the AI is, how many ♥♥♥♥ing bugs there are, and how unfair (in a very, very bad way) this game is. S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is one of my favorite series, but my god this game is a chore to play. All the little things start to really add up as you play through this game. I can usually deal with bugs, but this game is… far beyond repair. Even with ZRP installed, it is just a complete mess. THough it pains me to say it, avoid this one. The more you play it, the worse it gets. This game is a ♥♥♥♥ing disgrace to the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												I'll just say this up front: this game is not as good at Shadow of Chernobyl and Call of Pripyat. Not by a long shot: bullet sponge stalkers, buggy AI, generally linear storyline and map progression, lack of decent side quests, and wasted potential of the "Faction War" that is more of an exercise in patience than anything else. That said, Clear Sky is still a pretty good game, and for all its faults has a special place in my heart - even if I'm not entirely sure why. While the early patches "had more bugs than a crack ♥♥♥♥♥ with the sniffles" I've yet to crash with the steam version. Storyline could be better but is a good enough addition/prequel to the STALKER lore, and for all the frustration and unsatisfaction that will come the overall gameplay is still enjoyable. Plus GSC introduced or overhauled several things in this game that they went on to refine in CoP - weapon modifying, teams of stalkers, fast travel, anomaly fields, artifacts, faction relations, etc - so some stuff being rough around the edges is excusable. And who could forget the bandit polka!If you're a fan of the series, bought the SHoC/CoP bundle but still want more, or just are the style to play through games in order, it's worth the $10 to pick up, especially since the modding scene for it seems to be picking up these days. Give it a try, you won't regret it! Or at least, not till you try to make it past the army MG emplacement...

content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear SkyIt has been a while since I last played it, but after noticing some updates for some mods I used to play and the lack of a review, I decided to write this.Anyway... What can I say? An aweful lot, but I'm going to keep it short. This review will touch on two aspects of the game; modded and unmodded. ModdedI'm recommending this game because of mods. The S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series is among the most moddable game series out there. Despite this game being the weakest in the series, mods can quickly turn it into one of the strongest, if not the strongest. I've put more hours into this than I have into say, Shadow of Chernobyl or even Call of Pripyat (though between Misery and the recent release of Call of Chernobyl for CoP, my CoP playtime is catching up.Why? Simple really. A single mod called 'The Faction War' or TFW for short. It takes a wonderful mechanic brought into the series (but removed for some reason in CoP) and turns it into something more. What might this feature be? Faction wars, of course.Join one of the many factions and fight for supremacy, or go alone in the zone and fend for yourself against mutants, bandits or any factions you decide you don't like. It turns the game into an RTS of a sort, with reasonably large scale firefights - or, if you want to, quiet night-time operations.UnmoddedThe game is good without mods, but it is arguably the weakest in the series. It has an number of bugs which can be fixed through the use of mods and community patches. Other mods serve to enhance the story and gameplay, so by now you're getting the picture. You can play through the game fine, but you'll end up turning to mods to enhance, fix or even overhaul the game.I'll go into more detail another time, so for now this'll have to do.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												7/10Overview: First Person ShooterNote: I used the complete mod to play the game. The Good:+ Once again atmosphere is the main selling point of the game. The setting, locations and realistic art style really showcase the destruction of the Chernobyl incident.  The developers really nailed being in a destroyed post apocalyptic nuclear death zone. Buildings are crumbling and dilapidated, broken vehicles litter the roads, small settlements of makeshift homes and building house some of the other inhabitants on the 'zone'. Every aspect of the game facilitates you feeling like you need to survive. With the updated engine, the game looks even better than before+ lighting effects + A new addition is factions. You can join a faction to gain unique quests or help them out in general. Joining one faction usually puts you at odds with another. You can choose not to join anybody.+ Another new addition is the upgrade system. Different armors/weapons have different upgrades that you can choose to buy making them more powerful/effective in combat. In order to unlock certain upgrades you first have to find the blueprints, usually found in stashes or given as quests rewards.+ Side Quests have been improved somewhat over the first game. Money and quest rewards are more valuable than before and the quests are a bit more varied. Completing quests feels more meaningful. + Game play is nearly identical to the first game. Gameplay consists of killing enemies as you traverse 'the zone', scavenging dead bodies and loot to find weapons, armor, ammo, health etc. Survival is a main underlying component with the game. Weapons and armor degrade over time making them less effective and need to be fixed or replaced, radiation levels have to be checked, getting shot or attacked by mutant animals require you to use bandages to stop bleeding, eating is required every so often and you also need to watch your weight limit. Carry too much and your stamina runs out very quickly forcing you to stop or walk until you regain it back.  + Gun battles are fun, fast and furious. Certain main missions puts you in unique situations which makes gun fights more fun and satisfying. Certain battles reminded me heavily of Half Life 2. For example one mission has you making your way across a deserted town as you clear the road of enemies. Unlike the first game where gun fights usually took place as you traverse the open environment to your next objective, Clear Sky has more focused concise battles tailored to the specific level.  +Variety of different weapons that feel unique+Sound EffectsThe Average:With the addition of Factions also comes brain dead AI companions. Like most games, when you go into battle with your teammates, you will do the majority of killing while your 'teammates' sit back and relax. Teammates can also push you aside with ease - a big problem if your aiming down sights ready to make the crucial head shot only to have one of your squad member run into you pushing you aside messing up your aim. The game features most of the same location as the first game with a few new additions. It doesn't hurt the game by any means as the locations and level design is fantastic however I also find it a bit lazy when developers heavily reuse assets from the previous game. Long load times. Minor bugs and glitches.The Bad: - (Minor spoiler Alert) There is a part near the middle of the game where you lose all your money without warning. From a story perspective it makes sense, this is a hostile environment and anything can go bad at any minute. From a gameplay perspective this is awful. All the work that went into saving your money so that you can eventually buy your favorite piece of armor or weapon is now gone. Not only was I frustrated but my desire to accomplish any more side quests was also diminished. -Locating artifacts is a chore and almost unnecessary in this game. Artifacts are items that you can equip that grant you specific bonuses to your stats. In order to actually find these artifacts, you have to first equip your detector, than walk around the level in the hopes it will detect something for you to find. I found the process to be  time consuming and boring. This was a big downgrade from the previous game. - This game is hard even on the medium setting. Right from the start enemies can kill you with relative ease leading to some very frustrating moments causing me to abuse quick save/load. ConclusionAlthough the game certainly retains a lot of good things from the first game while improving on certain aspects, the overall package is not as good. The pacing and difficulty being the biggest culprits. The addition of factions is a really good idea but not implemented as well as it should have been.  I enjoyed my time with the game but I was glad it was over.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												-"Cheeki Breeki Simulator 2007"I'll start this off by saying that i've played the other games (SoC & CoP), which were brilliant post-apocalyptic RPG games, and while ClearSky may have much of the greatness of the other two games, it does seem to be the least brilliant of the three. I havent played enough to talk about this story-wise yet, but gameplay? Well, it isnt much different than the other two games and i'll even admit the NPCs in ClearSky came off pretty smart compared to the other two games. Thats about it. Rest of the gameplay is either up to par or slightly lacking. CoP had more beautiful enviroments, and SoC was generally more dramatic.This being said, ClearSky is the least awesome but still pretty awesome. I highly recomend this game, as well as the other two. Now, I would've given SoC a 9.5/10 and CoP would get a 9.6/10 but I think i'd have to give ClearSky an 8.3/10. It is a great game, just not as great as the other games in the series.

Posted: September 26, 2014
												Clear Sky, in it's untouched state was unplayable for me until I installed the COMPLETE mod. At that point the game opened itself up to me, and I'm loving it nearly as much as SoC. Like the original, it's initally unforgiving, with an excellent soundtrack and a seriously ominous and unnerving world. The map is improved to give the player more detail as to who is around them and what their function and intentions are, and the interactions between the different factions are a lot easier to interpret, which makes intervening and helping people out a lot easier. You spend a bit of time re-treading old locations, which can be a bit disappointing. However, the areas are occupied by different factions with different goals and it's kind of nice to see how the area changed over time between this game and the SoC, to which Clear Sky is a prequel.It also has some new graphical features, particularly when it comes to lighting, that really brings out some more polish in the game's visuals, and makes any action performed during nightime a terrifying affair. This is not my favourite of the Stalker series - that remains SoC - but the world is still compelling and oppressive as balls, and the core mechanics are more refined than those of its predecessor, so it certainly is worthy of the player's attention after finishing SoC.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2012
												Although all 3 Stalker games are fantastic, Clear Sky is my favourite. It is the most atmospheric of the 3, the most challenging, the biggest (yes it IS bigger than Call of Pripyat), and has the best soundtrack. Sadly it was also the buggiest at release and had some glichy cheating AI which coupled with the fairly high difficulty at the beginning put alot of people off. Everything been fixed up now more or less. It's still a tough game, especially the first few hours but put the time in and you will be rewarded with one of the all time great PC gaming experiences. I recommend it!

content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
												Clear Sky tries to follow its predecessor - and fails miserably. Just take a look at some of these awesome features!- Hardly any atmosphere, nothing compared to SoC- Characters that have little to no originality and - well - no character. They just sit there and talk. Or they run around and are meaningless. These will probably die soon.- Even more bugs than the first game- Ridiculous AI (sees you in the dark with your lamp off, behind things, inside foliage... just everywhere, but every time you have allies, they are the worst you could imagine)- Incredibly monotonous gameplay -> Just shoot. Kill entire armies of soldiers on your very own, over and over again. Well, if you can spare some time, deal with brutally pugnacious mutants. It doesn't matter what kind of enemy you encounter - they're all mostly bulletproof, unless you hit them multiple times in the head with high-end gear.I'll just add that I actually play the community made "Clear Sky Complete" mod that is meant to "ENHANCE" the entire thing... seriously don't wanna see the vanilla original.There is exactly one positive point about this game, but solely for those who played the first one:+ Many of the areas from SoC are recognizable, but a little different. Veterans will revel in memories. And the new portions of the map are quite interesting as well..........BUT: Don't celebrate too much - 'cause if you just fell in love being "home" at the Cordon or the Garbage again - well, enjoy, because you most likely won't get there a second time. The story line is just too linear to find any sense in travelling back. Well - all in all it's really sad. But I wanted to have the entire trilogy, so i got the bundle. At least it was on sale.

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19
												I found this game boring.  It lacked the authentic feel of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. game, and honestly felt like a collection of mods than a cohesive game.  The things I disliked about it:- Waiting bugs.  After capturing a location, the assignment of "Defend and Wait for Reinforcements" could take up to 30 minutes.  No way to advance the main campaign at that point.- Generic missions, of type "Go there and retrieve something."  I lost track of what I was retrieving, and for whom, especially since the sought item was usually in the clear with no one guarding it.  These were also part of the main campaign.- It's boring to accumulate money.  My armor wore out quickly, and I ended up spending a lot of money to patch it.  There were always scores of guns lying around, but with the limited weight capacity, I ended up running back and forth to sell all of them, just to get my armor back to 100%.  Made the game feel tedious.Ultimately, I ended up reading the walkthrough rather than watching/playing the rest of the game, because I lost almost all interest in it.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2012
												5/10, crappy end game. If you're new to Stalker series, play SoC or Call of Pripyat.Clear Sky has it's moments. There are lots of well designed environments for geocaching. Day/night cycles highlight game's excellent shadow system. Anomaly artifacts are rare enough. Game works a lot like Shadow of Chernobyl in most aspects.On down side, some missions aren't that much fun on harder difficulty levels, there is little or no benefits from finding hidden caches, Faction Wars seems like afterthought and won't lend much to gameplay after starting area. Looting corpses for money is very easy. But those problems aren't nothing compared how bad end game is which must be probably one of the worst I've played. It's time-constrained pipe-running in midst of one-shotting grenade-spam enemies spawning from thin air. If you eventually grind it through by memorizing enemy positions, bugged end game makes you finally turn difficulty down and restarting from auto-save. Or go to YouTube for end video.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												(Before reading this review, read my review of stalker shadow of Chernobyl) http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561197984765152/recommended/4500/(And just like before I played this game on the highest difficulty and WITHOUT MODS, and don’t start whining at me saying you need to use mods) Clear sky is a prequel and near the end happens at the same time as shadow of Chernobyl. In clear sky you play as a mercenary called Scar who is able to survive emissions and ends up working with the faction Clear sky, whose goal is to stop Strelok from reaching the middle of the zone where it is believed something catastrophic with happen.Clear sky does add a few new things into the game since now you can upgrade and repair weapons and armour, artefacts are much rarer and you need a detector to find them, you now have guides who can take you into different places, you can side with most factions, you now need slots for artefacts and you must have a minus radiation value artefact if you have a plus radiation one to counter it otherwise you will slowly die of radiation poisoning, and the hunger and thirst system was removed so food now just acts as health items and energy drinks are just to boost your stamina, but other than that this is very much the same as shadow of Chernobyl. Clear sky also improves a few things that were in shadow of Chernobyl, the map and PDA have been improved, most of the weapons are a bit more accurate than the previous game but they still aren’t great, moving is no longer headache inducing, and thankfully loading quick saves won’t cause the enemies to go back to their starting positions which can be right next to or in front or behind you and you'll get killed instantly. This is still a strangely compelling game but it still comes with problems from the previous game and it adds its own. The gunfights aren’t anywhere near as to what they were in the previous game but it is still a little random on whether you’ll get shot or not and the damage output. The amount of bandages and med kits used to stop you from bleeding out is random to the point where sometimes it will only take one bandage, but other times you can go through all of the bandages and med kits in your inventory. The map is incorrect with the directions used to go to this one area that’s south east of the red forest, you’d think you’d have to go to the exit pointing south east but that takes you to Garbage, you actually have to go to the NORTH exit point to get to the area that is SOUTH EAST of the red forest. The height difference between standing and crouching is two or three inches. Enemies can now throw grenades, they can throw grenades from over 100 yards away and they explode a second after they land and this is really annoying when you are trying to kill a group of enemies only to have a few grenades land at your feet.Your weapons jam far too often.Just like shadow of Chernobyl getting this game all comes down to whether you think you can put up with these problems and I actually enjoyed this a bit more than shadow of Chernobyl to a certain extent.

The map is incorrect with the directions used to go to this one area that’s south east of the red forest, you’d think you’d have to go to the exit pointing south east but that takes you to Garbage, you actually have to go to the NORTH exit point to get to the area that is SOUTH EAST of the red forest. The height difference between standing and crouching is two or three inches. Enemies can now throw grenades, they can throw grenades from over 100 yards away and they explode a second after they land and this is really annoying when you are trying to kill a group of enemies only to have a few grenades land at your feet.Your weapons jam far too often.Just like shadow of Chernobyl getting this game all comes down to whether you think you can put up with these problems and I actually enjoyed this a bit more than shadow of Chernobyl to a certain extent.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												The stupid brother of SoC and COPI loved Stalker SoC and CoP and finishes both several times. But Clear Sky has just too many flaws. First the difficulty is quite high, what i usually like. But it`s not high because the enemies are very clever. They are not dumb either and gun fights can be really fun, when you are not pushed in the line of fire by a NPC or because even simple bandits see you in the dark while you can`t even see the weapon in your hand. They will shoot you from far far away with with their rusty pistols. The problem is you can`t skip the night, so you have to wait for an hour realtime(!) or so untill it becomes day or you will die even more often than you already do during daytime. And then the controls: Awful! Who ever came up with the idea that you actually have two kinds of crouching from which one is such a small change to your standing position, that it`s more or less useless and the other one is only possible to execute, when you are crouched in the first postion beforehand. Who ever invented this should be banned from making videos games for ever. So you die most often because of the crappy controls and poor design choices and not because of the smart enemies. Two examples for how bad the level design can be: The beginning of the game in the swamps. 1st. The Water is radioactive and will kill you, but because of the high grass, you can`t see it most of the time. So you just stare at the map ignoring 98% of the screen to make your way and try to follow the totaly random and confusing mission messeges which are popping up every few seconds. One second a mission starts "defend x" a second later (you had no chance to get there in time) " mission defedning x canceled" and you don`t even know why. So You run in the opposite direction (staring at the map) to do another mission like the first one. But then again the first mission popps up again: "defend x". And a few more seconds later these missions can be canceled again or fail without any chance to accomplish them.  At another point the game leads you to a spot out of a canal where you are supposed start a mission in a new area, but there is no way to pass the MG-nest which lies between you and the area where you need to go. You are literary sitting in a trap , sourrounded by barbwire, while on the only open side the machinegun awaits to kill you in a split second. This is by far the worst level design I have seen in a game for a long time. For the whole game F5 and F9 will be your most used keys. You will look at the loading screen like alot. And that`s the reason why there is never a constant flow of gaming. There is no chance that Clear Sky developes an atmosphere like the one the other stalker games are known for. It`s just not enjoyable and that`s a shame, because the other two games are awesome. Play these and skip this one, you are not missing anything.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2015
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R Clear Sky is a Prequel to the original S.T.A.L.K.E.R Shadow of Chernobyl. Released in 2008, It tells an alternate timeline story of "The Zone", which is the highly contaminated and radioactive area surrounding the Chernobyl Nuclear Plant and neighboring areas, after a second explosion occurs at the plant. S.T.A.L.K.E.R's are scavengers who traverse the Zone in search of Artifacts, as Guides, Mercenaries, and for research related operations. In this prequel, which is recommended prior to playing S.T.A.L.K.E.R Shadow of Chernobyl, you play as a S.T.A.L.K.E.R known as Scar, who is injured by an unknown energy emission, while escorting scientists through the zone. Somehow Scar survives and finds himself at Clear Sky, a research colony trying to understand what is happening to the Zone. From here you begin your journey into the Zone, to unlock it's mysteries, as well as to save Clear Sky from the dangers at their gates. S.T.A.L.K.E.R Clear Sky, came after S.T.A.L.K.E.R Shadow of Chernobyl, so it plays much the same way. You have a set amount of inventory space, an array of weaponry to loot or purchase, armor to help keep you alive, as well as medpac's, bandages, grenades and more. Mods exist for the S.T.A.L.K.E.R games, which are extremely popular such as The Stalker Complete set, Misery, and the Oblivion Mod, all of which, change the game mechanics and overhaul the games graphics. S.T.A.L.K.E.R has been a decent Horror FPS series, and spawned another sequel following the events of Shadow of Chernobyl called, S.T.A.L.K.E.R Call of Pripyat. If you like games such as Fear, Resident Evil, Silent Hill, you should enjoy S.T.A.L.K.E.R Clear Sky. Again, it is the second game in the series, but is meant to be a prequel to S.T.A.L.K.E.R Shadow of Chernobyl, so I recomment playing Clear Sky first.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2012
												GSC Game World had an unexpected hit with S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl and they keep the momentum going by developing a prequel and pushing it out the door in about a year and a half after Shadow's release.S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky had some tough shoes to fill. Expectations were very high and whlist it can't match the first for gameplay, it manages to deliver on the atmosphere and adds some new gameplay elements which can be considered either frustrating or brilliant.You play as Zone guide and veteran S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Scar who, after amazingly surviving a deadly emission, is rescued by an unknown faction known as Clear Sky. Located in the Swamps, you must work with them secretly to find out why the zone is getting worse.The game is a 50/50 mix of areas seen in Shadow of Chernobyl and brand new areas. The old areas have some pretty big changes to them and areas that were safe in the first game might be a complete nightmare this time around and vice versa.The game focuses a lot of its first half on the war between the various factions located in the Zone. You are free, once outside the Swamps, to join any faction you want (Freedom, Duty, Stalkers, even the Bandits) and have the privliges that faction offers, all whilst still secretly working for the Clear Sky faction that saved your life.The game has had some of its more interesting elements removed; your character no longer needs to eat and drink to stay alive, the systems for detecting how visible you are and how much noise you are making have also been removed.Finding artifacts is now a bit more challenging then before; in Shadow of Chernobyl they would be bobbing up and down in random places around the Zone and you could just run up to them and pick them up maybe whilst avoiding some anomolies. In Clear Sky, artifacts are now invisible but you have a detector that can guide you to them, you just have to work your way through the deadly anomalies, get close to it and it appears for you to collect. This risk/reward mechanism enhances the values of artifacts greatly.The story sadly isn't as interesting as the first game and instead of most of the spoken dialogue being in Ukranian like in the first game, it has been translated into very rough English that sounds forced and out of place. This can take away from some of the atmosphere of being a foreigner in a completely strange environment.The game also has a nasty habit of making enemies invincible unless you are close enough. No more picking off people from a distance which can be incredibly frustrating at times.It isn't as good as Shadow of Chernobyl story-wise and mechanicly but the atmosphere and general improvements make up for it. A worthy addition to the series and worth playing!P.S. You can grab the "CLEAR SKY COMPLETE" modification to fix crash to desktop bugs and translation problems.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												Great game. 8/10.Graphics are amazing, and still beautiful in 2015. I played it a long time ago and it's even better now than I remember. Patched up pretty well, doesn't crash or glitch as much as it used to. In fact, it never crashed when I played it this time round, except a couple of times when fiddling with settings. AI is so much better than in Shadow of Chernobyl, and dialogue is voiced (not your character's voice unfortunately), even has full English dialogue (half of combat shouting is in Russian, and it's better that way).Super immersive, nice music. There is a bug with music where it randomly cuts off when exploring, dunno what's with that. Pretty unfortunate considering the ambient music when exploring is fantasticly immersive. Also ambient sounds are great. Dynamic music in settings is bleh, it basically turns on combat music to play when in combat, and that isn't really fun.Storyline is magnificent, and graphics are insane. This game was made in '08 and has god rays, bump maps, the lot. The Map is huge, exploring is extremely rewarding and side quests are fun. Extremely well optimized as well for both nVidia and AMD cards. Great game.My biggest problem with it is the ending mission and cutscene. The cutscene left too much in the open, it didn't really explain that everyone was being brainwashed or whatever, or that this is how stalkers are made into fanatic monolith worshippers. The ending mission was just a disaster, once you (SPOILERS AHEAD) enter Chernobyl NPP you're supposed to attack Strelok, and honestly it feels like they rushed the game at the end there. Pretty bad mission. Fully scripted and badly made. Like a mission I would've made in Spore Galactic Adventures. Animations were terrible in the end, jesus.So the final mission was super anti-climatic and actually more hilarious and sad than anything else. Too bad, for such a great game. Kinda like Mass Effect 3, I guess. Lowered my rating from 9 to 8.Oh yeah, and I recommend playing in master difficulty, so much more fun and realistic that way. Headshots are instakills.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												This is an odd game in the series. It has a heavier focus on combat over anomolies. My main complaint was the mess that is the Faction Wars, lopsided sides mean either a battle up or downhill depending on your faction, assuming you can even finish without squads getting stuck or endless assaults. It is a solid game, but it gives way to linear final areas with little warning leaving your character possibly VERY under prepared.Despite this fans have unofficial mods and patches that greatly enhance the game. Overall I got 35 hours out of it, being the fan of the STALKER series I have to say it is worth playing at least once. I value it at $20, considering it's normal price is $10 if it goes on a steam sale definitely worth a buy.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												STALKER Clear Sky review, by Filthy NickGraphics:-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Well the graphics aren't that good, the game runs on the X-RAY 1.5 engine, it's a very old engine, I  beleve it was introduced somewhere in 2002. with Oblivion Lost (Yes, STALKER was suposed  to be called Oblivion Lost). Xray engine is full of bugs. Damn bugs, anyway this is the Xray engine 1.5 so it's in the "top form". It's stable if you use the vanila game.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Gameplay:--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------STALKER is one of those games, when you start playing them you just can't stop, it's too good, my favorite thing about this game is the faction war (install Clear Skies mod for the better expiriance), you feel like the factions are in a real war. At the very start of the game you need to clear out the Regenade scum so that Clear Sky can take over the swamp.When you are short on cash there is always artefact hunting, with a detector you can find these things so called artefacts, you can sell them for a nice ammount of cash. The worst thing is when you are in a fight and then your weapon jams, that one second may be the diference bettwen life and death, that's why you always need to reparir your gear.Clear Sky is the first STALKER game that features weapons/suit upgrades, every upgrade has its pros and cons. Weapons in this game use a realistic bullet physics, they have tracers and everything, bullets will fall after some time so don't expect to kill somebody that is 200m from  you with no calculation or what so ever.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------VERDICT:Would I recomend this game? ♥♥♥♥ yeah I would, I got this on steam just because there was a sale, I have the retail version of the game. Oh yeah , all of you who bought the game as a retail copy I suggest you buy it on steam, steam  version is really stable unlike the retail version.8/10Engine is old, gameplay is damn good, crashes sometimes, get mods for it, it's way better with mods.

												While it has its issues, this game and the series as a whole contain(s) a unique atmosphere not found in any other series that meshes the elements of RPG, first person shooter, and a bit of survival horror together in an amazing way. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2013
												Consider this a recommendation for the entire STALKER series so far (latest as of this being Call of Pripyat). The STALKER games are FPS/Survival Horror/RPG hybrids where the emphasis is on the FPS gunplay and the survival elements.You can get thirsty or hungry or need sleep and have to manage those needs alongside that of the deteriorating conditions of your weapons and armors. Ammunition, food, and drink needed to survive are scarce, but can be traded for with almost anyone if you have the right amount of goods or money to sacrifice for it. The game has large maps you can travel between like a sandbox game, and the gunplay is some of the tightest I've seen with really good gun physics. The games also have a wildlife simulation system similar to the one in place in FarCry 3 in a way; animals and mutants will run around and do their own thing after they spawn and kill each other (and maybe you) for survival or food.Despite the large amount of freedom these games afford you to carve your own path, they feel very focused and are best approached with a strategic mindset.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												Unpopular opinion, but Clear Sky is the best STALKER-game imo. I really love the settings, the weather variations, the fractions makes sense. The fractionwars is also a really cool feature. Just make sure to choose the right faction. For example, I really hated the Red Forest as it scared the sh*t out of me so I sided with Duty to get the guides for fast travelling to guide me to the safe spot in Red Forest. That, on the other hand made me an enemy to Freedom, which controls most of the Military Warehouses, making that area even harder than it already is with mutants, Zombiefied and Monoliths. But the point is, the option to join factions and wage war is totally awesome.One bad thing is that there is no 'cheatcommands' in the console for this game. You dont like cheating? Well neither do I, but lets make something very clear, Clear Sky is full of bugs. For instance, after I conquered Freedoms base with Duty, Freedom launched an assault on their old base, I was inside, and Duty locked the doors. So basically no-one could get in or out. On the plus side, its really easy to install mods that allow you to ghost/noclip through doors and resolve the issue. Also you can get stuck in holes and betwewen rocks and cant get out. These mods helps with that.The storyline is also really cool, but so are the storylines in the other STALKER games. I wont say anything about it to avoid spoiling it.So to summarize it, a really cool game in a postapocalyptic Chernobyl/Ukrainian rural area full with mutated animals, monsters, Stalkers(humans) and filled with anomalies and artifacts, extremely dangerous weather and some cool East and West-based weapon that you can customize and modify to suit your needs.The story itself isnt that long, you could easily get this game done in a couple of hours. But the sidequests, and of course the fraction wars, litterally eats your time up. And if that wasnt enough, there are tons of mods that adds new content. For the small prize it costs nowadays, there is nothing to think about. Buy it.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												I enjoyed this game a lot when it first came out. It's highly customizable and there is a huge community constantly pumping out mods and tweaks for this series.You play a russian scoundral, your goal is to infiltrate the zone (Chernobyl). Along the way you will meet mutant pig dogs, cows with human faces, bandits, freedom fighters, nazis, scientists. You name it.The world is basically persistent and you will have to do things to aid your particular faction, like kill bandits or mutants, find vodka, whatever.  The different npc factions are constantly fighting over parts of the zone and you are caught in the middle.Will you become a stoner and join the freedom faction?Will you become a cold hearted killer and join the duty faction?It's up to you, run around and kill stuff and steal radio-active thingys that give you bonus states. If you are a sci-fi fan or a shooter fan you should definitely try this game.
