number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												I've never played the other S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games but I have played my fair share of Post Apocalyptic games, and I gotta say, this one's my favorite. It forces you to use your brain to survive, the Zone is a rough place and only the best can survive, I've died at least 100 times in the short time I had with it. When facing a situation, it's up to you, the player to figure out how your going to deal or get out of it. The AI are by no means stupid, but neither are they smart. They have a predicible patern when fighting but yet they still seem to surprise me. At night is when I feel I have the most advantage, if I have a silenced weapon or knife I can actually, quote on quote, "Stalk my prey"  because the AI can't see well at night, if they hear me but don't know where I am specifically, they'll shoot randomly in my direction. The darkness is hard to get used but other games I play like Skyrim or Fallout, I have lighting mods making the night and dungeons much darker so I've become quite adept at night fighting. All the weapons seem to have an ungodly amount of spread, which gives me the vibe that Scar is nervous. And why shouldn't he be, half the time I have to take on a camp of 15 enimies on my own. I recommend this game for the hardcore PA game players, not just someone who's played New Vegas on easy with a bunch of OP modded guns, not a game for casual gamers

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												Fantastic game! I've been interested in the Chernobyl NPP accident for a while. S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky is the second installment in the franchise. It was released in 2008. The S.T.A.L.K.E.R. franchise is the only game franchise in the world that is about the Chernobyl disaster except for "Chernobyl: Terrorist Attack". The game is about a second explosion at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant (NPP) near Pripyat in Ukraine. The game takes place in 2011. The game has great atmosphere, I don't really think that the graphics are that bad. I think they are good enough. Sure it doesn't look like Battlefield 1 or something but the graphics are a part of the experience! It's really challenging and the way you walk around alone out in the dark at night is terrifying, you feel like someone is going to sneak up on you and kill you. Weapons are pretty much the same as the other S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games, but they are kinda unique. NPCs are great, sometimes they might not react to get shot at but they are mostly good. The mutants are powerful and scary. Enviroment is very detailed and it's beautiful for being a nuclear exclusion zone. It's dark and scary. Love it! You should definetly get it!

content:
Posted: November 17, 2011
												This game was sort of a rip-off. You start in this new area/base of comrades called Clear Sky. But once you're done, you quickly find yourself back in Cordon and the usual places from the first S.T.A.L.K.E.R game. Same place, different quests. However in addition to Clear Sky, there are some new places. I remember a new town which you can see from the second trailer and I remember a forest area with some freakish spherical anomaly. The third trailer also shows some new content, which I remember being friggen hard.Like the first game: Initially you might get overwhelmed with all these buttons you have to learn. It's almost like a simulator genre in that respect. But the learning curve is moderate and you'll quickly know what items are important and what to disregard.Re-occurring quests can become annoying. It's quite random and there's nothing to say whether you have completed the quest or not. In fact S.T.A.L.K.E.R is the only FPS RPG I know where you can fail quests a few times.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												Firstly S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Clear Sky is almost and exact clone of S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Shadow of Chernobyl with some small areas introduced and others removed. I see no problem with this as the story is different and compelling and the introduction of a weapon customization menu was a big step towards S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Call of Pripyat where the game was perfected. However this eddition of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R series has many less mods avaliable for it and there are many unbalanced aspects to the gameplay which are removed. If you have the money for all three S.T.A.L.K.E.R games get this! As a veteran of the zone playing far upwards of my logged online hours i would recommend the S.T.A.L.K.E.R series in the following order:S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Call of PripyatS.T.A.L.K.E.R: Shadow of ChernobylS.T.A.L.K.E.R: Clear SkyIf you love a strong story i'd suggest S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Shadow of Chernobyl, but if, like me, you prefer maximized gameplay and a balanced combat system allowing you to aquire your favorite gun right away, then upgrade it to a monster as your progress i'd suggest S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Call of Pripyat.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2012
												-Core Review-Gameplay . 8Music . 6Graphics . 8Mechanics . 7.5Story(s) . 8Total . 7.5-Nice Words-Fun solo adventure, immersive environment, well built characters. That's what you'll find in S.T.A.L.K.E.R. (Clear Sky). This game might or might not give you the spooks, and will definitely have you running around for hours trying to figure some things out. Over all its a beautiful game and I recommend it to most everyone.-Personal Experience / Old Review-To give you a idea of how confusing this game is, the first time I played it I thought it was in Russian. Waking up in the middle of a house in a small town where people pull guitars out of there asses after being blown up in a giant nuclear explosion totally makes sense, as does the rest of this game. This post-nuclear-war game has you wondering who turned off the lights whenever it is night time. Usually in most FPS games ammo is always around the corner but I find myself walking to the next town just to get 60 of my trusty bullets, and I'll definitely have enough time to carve all of my mutated targets names on them by the time I get back to where i originally started.This game has a great sense of atmosphere and has a story, that starts out unusually so I suggest playing the first one. However it is one of the best single player games I've touched, and by that I mean the series.Also turrets are OP

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												First I want to say that this game is extremely difficult, even on "Stalker" (Normal). Near the end of the game you will not be able to purchase bandages or medkits, and trust me you will need them. If you run out of medkits you will have to turtle your way through massive and very cheap spawning enemies. Now I don't think this is a bad game, if it was intended to be hard then they nailed it. The problems I have with it are such:-Enemies have a hitbox inefficiency, some enemies take massive amounts of ammo (1-2 clips) and others take a few shots even if they are the same. Don't bother aiming for the head it works on the lesser enemies.-The game goes from a really decent RPG to a linear shooting gallery where you hind behind numerous walls and crates with a "hold" crouch which does not fit well. -The ending of the game is something that unless you find out ahead of time you will never beat it. Unless you see that you need ungodly amounts of medkits and bandages "YOU WILL NOT WIN".-There are bugs yes but sometimes freaking out and hitting the move keys enough you can get out. If not you better have saved recently. -Autosaves are only when you go to new areas, other than that if you don't save you will be playing this game a very long time.-Gun upgrading is expensive for the lack of money you normally have. Plus the weapon will lower in condition very quickly so money in this game is your best friend.-Finally, the money, if you don't farm and chore through the swamps and all the anomalies to find artifaces or pick up every gun you see, you will have "NO" money. Other than these things I find that it is weirdly addicting and quite fun and funny sometimes. If you like really hard games well this game is great.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												Quick overall:Play this game as what it is: an action/adventure FPS. This is NOT A RPG and this is NOT A SURVIVAL game. You just shoot things that appear in your way (and loot their corpses) in order to advance in the linear plot.There's no moral decisions to be made, no different paths to follow, no interesting characters to know, no customization of the abilities of your character, no basic needs that you need to fulfill from time to time. It seems the developers kinda started shaping it into a RPG (big maps, side-missions, inventory system), but aborted the idea. If you deal with it as an action/adventure FPS, it's an OK game. Another thing: I played it with the "Road to Limansk" mod, which corrects some bugs of the vanilla game and I recommend.THE GOOD- Solid gameplay, weapons fire nicely and each one feels different from another. You can have readily equipped a main gun, a side weapon and grenades, besides a Geiger-counter stuff to locate artifacts (stones that give you some bonuses). There are many upgrades that can be made in your weapons and armor. You can walk/run/crouch/jump effectively, running and jumping use stamina.- The density of individuals in the map is good: there are few NPCs wandering around (Ukraine Exclusion Zone, after all), but not few enough to the point that it would make the game boring. BTW, the map of the game is divided in separate regions; in order to go from one to another, there's a loading screen.- There's a "faction system" that, albeit simple, works. If two enemy factions meet randomly on the map, there will be gunfight. A faction's outpost may be overrun by another faction's guys from time to time. Also, you can belong to some faction of your choice if you want to.- Interesting setting: Ukraine Exclusion Zone.- Good diversity of items to loot, and the inventory is somewhat realistic regarding weight.- Nice graphics without stressing your pc. Some landscapes and building are quite impressive for a 2008 game.- Some interesting mods available with which you can customize your game.THE BAD- Generic characters. With the exception of some few key characters that have a bigger array of dialogue lines, are partially voiced and have a visible face (things that just diminish their blandness), the random guy has some 3 whatever dialogue lines, is not voiced and doesn't even have a visible face (ALL of them use some cloth or helmet to hide it). All of them use the same body model and move exactly the same. Besides, in my 28 hours of game I didn't see a single woman, NPCs are all male so far.- The side-missions are not only bland, but too quick. It's the same old "go there/get that" style of mission, but instead of going through immense caves or labyrinthical forgotten vaults to "get that", you just walk some 200m, open a crate, walk back and collect your reward.- Lack of lore-elements to enrich the Exclusion Zone setting. There are no pieces of lore to be found/seen, like diaries, newspapers, radio stations, books, texts or things like that regarding the context of the game. I know, we can read about the real Exclusion Zone in Wikipedia, but the game's one is different and we can't go deep on it.- Soundtrack as generic as the characters. Generic techno beat during the action and generic ambient music outside of action moments. Play the game with music off.- Corrupt save-files. Sometimes your saves don't load. I heard that it happens after some scripted event in the game. I had this issue with 2 saves, after that I started quick-saving and hard-saving in 2 different slots before transitioning from one region to another. Haven't had problems after that.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2013
												Played this one thru with the Clear Sky COMPLETE mod.    I guess the simplest thing to say about STALKER is that it has an amazing and engrossing atmosphere, but the game itself is marred by bugs and clunky implementation of mechanics.  Looting and surviving thru the hauntingly beautiful and dreadful zone is an experience worth having.  Putting up with a quest glitching, and having to go back 2 hours worth of gameplay to find a save that will reset it, is not...  Luckily the complete mod comes with a "wish granter" cheat menu that can mitigate some of the bugs and flaws with mechanics.Specifically, the faction wars in Clear Sky were pretty much broken for me.  When I joined Duty they would not take the first base after I cleared it.  So I was stuck with Freedom trying to kill me all game without any rewards for it.  It also broke the sense of isolation since you'd hear firefights breaking out every 4 or 5 minutes.   The final battle was an overly scripted inconsistent sort of mess. 8/10

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky, is the prequel to S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl, a first-person shooter survival horror video game with RPG elements by Ukrainian developer GSC Game World. The game consists of a roughly 50/50 mix of new areas and old, remodeled areas from the previous game. The X-ray graphics engine has been updated to version 1.5 and includes DirectX 10 support . Additionally, the AI received an overhaul to accommodate the new faction wars feature.

												For as much bad stuff I've heard about this, it's actually really great (as long as you play with the Complete mod), and actually has a lot of stuff I wish SoC and CoP had. The biggest fault I've seen is some stupidity in the AI - such as I was stuck on the very first mission for 3 hours due to one Flesh laying in some tall grass miles away from anybody yet it stopped my guys from getting to where they needed to be to finish the mission.Aside that it's got a lot of cool stuff and the Zone feels more realistic, with many of the mutants just acting like natural animals instead of running in circles into the same anomaly over and over such as in SoC, and making friends actually being important - unlike SoC and CoP where they do nothing to help you ever in return. There's a lot of other things like the NPC's giving cover fire for each other, blind-firing when it makes sense to do, proper use of cover I don't see in even modern games, and so on. Oh and the voice acting is best of the 3.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 20, 2010
												Combining my favorite game genres, Stalker is an FPSRPG you just shouldn't miss. A prequel to Shadow of Chernobyl, it takes a lot of maps from the original game and a few new areas of its own, with a new twist and improved gameplay mechanics.  It's unique system creates gameplay scenarios you really can't find anywhere else. A game worth playing if you enjoy survival games. There are plenty of mods to choose from as well, but if you want to play a modded game, you'll usually have to start a new one. You can't decide in the middle of the game you don't like something, and go find a mod to fix it, most require a fresh start entirely. Definitely do-able without mods, though there are some frustrating things that were never fixed (like NPC nade spam) and some bugs or quirks to address. Doesn't hurt to do a little reading up first, to decide if you'd like a vanilla or modded experiance your first time through.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												Firstly S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Clear Sky is almost and exact clone of S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Shadow of Chernobyl with some small areas introduced and others removed. I see no problem with this as the story is different and compelling and the introduction of a weapon customization menu was a big step towards S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Call of Pripyat where the game was perfected. However this eddition of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R series has many less mods avaliable for it and there are many unbalanced aspects to the gameplay which are removed. If you have the money for all three S.T.A.L.K.E.R games get this! As a veteran of the zone playing far upwards of my logged online hours i would recommend the S.T.A.L.K.E.R series in the following order:S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Call of PripyatS.T.A.L.K.E.R: Shadow of ChernobylS.T.A.L.K.E.R: Clear SkyIf you love a strong story i'd suggest S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Shadow of Chernobyl, but if, like me, you prefer maximized gameplay and a balanced combat system allowing you to aquire your favorite gun right away, then upgrade it to a monster as your progress i'd suggest S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Call of Pripyat.

Posted: November 17, 2011
												This game was sort of a rip-off. You start in this new area/base of comrades called Clear Sky. But once you're done, you quickly find yourself back in Cordon and the usual places from the first S.T.A.L.K.E.R game. Same place, different quests. However in addition to Clear Sky, there are some new places. I remember a new town which you can see from the second trailer and I remember a forest area with some freakish spherical anomaly. The third trailer also shows some new content, which I remember being friggen hard.Like the first game: Initially you might get overwhelmed with all these buttons you have to learn. It's almost like a simulator genre in that respect. But the learning curve is moderate and you'll quickly know what items are important and what to disregard.Re-occurring quests can become annoying. It's quite random and there's nothing to say whether you have completed the quest or not. In fact S.T.A.L.K.E.R is the only FPS RPG I know where you can fail quests a few times.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Clear Sky is the black sheep and a bit of a stopgap game in the STALKER series. It has massive gameplay improvements over Shadow of Chernobyl, but uncharacteristically focuses on large scale faction warfare and is missing the most interesting areas and underground sections that SoC had. It isn't a bad game, it's simply a bit obsolete because SoC has more content and all the gameplay improvements can now also be found in Call of Pripyat. Worst of all, the faction system which was this game's main draw was broken by the official patches and doesn't function as intended anymore.I can only recommend Clear Sky if you get it in a bundle or have already played both of the other games and simply want to see every possible STALKER experience there is.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												The first Swamps level is probably the best thing about Clear Sky -- it really does feel like it is building on Shadow of Chernobyl to greater heights! Unfortunately, it builds the game up to a level it cannot sustain.It's kind of cool to revist a lot of the same places and see them in a slightly different light. But by the time you are going through the Agroprom and Yantar, the novelty begins to wear off.Add in the numerous bugs and outright crashes towards the end of the game, even with the Complete mod, and I was seriously getting frustrated towards the end of my 150-hour playthrough. Oh, and the final act feels rushed, just like it did in SoC. And don't even get me STARTED on the final level! Argh!Still, the nod to the film Stalker in the penultimate level is very nice, though it is a shame the game rushes you through it without too much chance to revel in the environments.Overall -- definitely weaker and less polished that SoC Complete, but still, I managed to clock up a good amount of hours out of Clear Sky. It never quite manages to surpass its opening, though, which is a shame.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky is the prequel to S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl. I recently delved into this game again, and I figure I should review it. S.T.A.L.K.E.R. has always had a focus on factions, but Clear Sky soups up the faction system like crazy. You can join any of the not-immediately-hostile major factions (i.e. Military and Monolith), which include, off the top of my head, Duty, Freedom, Bandits, Loners, and Clear Sky. You get special gear for joining specific factions. I prefer Duty, personally.The gameplay is solid, although it's essentially the same as Shadow of Chernobyl but touched up a little bit. The accuracy is dictated by whether or not you are crouching, or if you are using iron sights. You bleed if you are shoot in a non-vital spot, so do enemies. Enemies, if hit in a location that bleeds a lot, will eventually keel over and die or curl up on the ground dying. If you hit an enemy in the head, it's an instant kill, unless they are armored up with some of the more powerful gear, or unless they are a zombie. I think it takes 2 or 3 shots to the head to drop a zombie or a guy wearing an exoskeleton.A big perk of this game that they added in Clear Sky is the upgrade system. You can attach/detach silencers and scopes, as you could in SoC, but now you can go to NPCs who can upgrade your weapons and armor. You can upgrade gear with composite plates, extra carry weight, artifact slots, etc., and improve accuracy, fire rate, recoil, and even reduce bullet drop and change ammunition type on some weapons.For those who played SoC, artifacts are significantly harder to find in this game. Rather than being able to see artifacts, you need to find them with an anomalous activity tracker, which will track them with beeps. I strongly suggest getting to Yantar ASAP and upgrading that puppy to one that has a map attached to it.I feel like there is more to do in this game than SoC, with the faction wars and such. But it does seem like there are less side-missions. That's kind of a con I suppose. Anyway:This game has a lot of pros: The combat is interestingly difficult and forces you to think out your combat encounters, or have your entire carry weight taken up by medkits (Don't do that, that's a terrible idea). The faction system and faction wars are awesome. The upgrades are neat, the game is gorgeous, and blah blah blah.On cons: This game suffers from pretty much the same issues that Shadow of Chernobyl did. Those are bugs, lots of bugs, the game tends to crash every so often (Quicksave! F5 is your friend. Do it often!), and... An issue I had with SoC that I still have with this game, is that it has an ABSURD difficulty spike in the last act of the game. I can't help but find it irritating. You have a set-up and souped up gear that has allowed you to breeze through everthing else, and then come the last act, you feel like you're wearing the leather hoodie you start off with, equipped with a... I don't know... BB gun.Anyway, this game is an excellent game, it should be played.

Waking up in the middle of a house in a small town where people pull guitars out of there asses after being blown up in a giant nuclear explosion totally makes sense, as does the rest of this game. This post-nuclear-war game has you wondering who turned off the lights whenever it is night time. Usually in most FPS games ammo is always around the corner but I find myself walking to the next town just to get 60 of my trusty bullets, and I'll definitely have enough time to carve all of my mutated targets names on them by the time I get back to where i originally started.This game has a great sense of atmosphere and has a story, that starts out unusually so I suggest playing the first one. content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												Don't listen to the whiners, this game is AMAZING; even if you havent played the others in the series. Its the prequel to SOC, but with much more faction-based gameplay and a seemingly endless reservoir of randomly generated side quests. I loved clear sky because it places you in a constantly changing environment. For example; some areas will be covered by your guys at one moment, and then bandits or mutants will come in and (attempt to) take over. Sometimes your guys fare well on their own, other times they get evicerated. All of this can happen at any time and in any location no matter where you are in chernobyl. Its an excellent game for both intensive focused gamers AND casuals. The S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series is definately one of my all time favorite survival/horror FPSs, and Clear Sky is just as good of an example as any.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 20, 2015
												Clear Sky is a strange mix of spectacular and infuriating. The new areas are excellent and provide a good start and end, while the areas reused from SoC get a slight face lift. Typical stalker gameplay {treasure hunting, mutant hunting, and man hunting} mesh well with the newly implemented faction wars. Claiming territory is fun and rewarding, though it occasionally. doesn't work. If you take an area alone, members of your faction will refuse to take it and smaller land grabs are often abandoned as soon as they are taken. The game crashes constantly for the first two hours of the game. Once you get past the first few missions, crashing becomes a rarity. Common bugs include weather changing when quick loading and enemies losing interest in you after quick loading. Grenades are especially evil this time around. Your grenades are difficult to aim and enemies will side step them easily. Enemies on the other hand, can snipe you with grenades. At one point a bandit 400 paces away killed me with a cooked grenade that hit me as I stood near a third floor window. This entry, having focued on turf warfare between humans, has much less mutant encounters than the other entries. Despite it's flaws, Clear Sky is still a damned good game, and worth paying about $5 to play.

EDIT: The text below was written before Steam Recommendations became Steam Reviews.A prequel for S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl, Clear Sky offers more adventures in the radioactive Zone around the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant. It's not as extensive and adds only a few new locations, but mainly it wants the player to revisit some well known places from the previous part. It has the same heavy atmosphere, worse plot and a next batch of bugs, the ones concerning the new war of factions system are especially serious and may force the player to reload the previous saved state. Recommended for fans of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. universe.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												-gameplay and content: The atmosphere is awesome and incredible.however KI is sometimes dumb and sometimes frankly unfair (enemy grenades fly far and very precisely, hitting you an any angle as long as you are within the ridiculous range. oh and by the way, you cannot throw as far as the enemy nor with such precision). some characters also like to run at each other forever due to collision and pathfinding issues and sometimes they get stuck at doors etc. they also like to block you due to the same reasons.weapon-safezones: at the HQ of every faction and important person you can not draw your weapon. this takes a lot from the freedom feeling the game normally creates. Supposedly it is to protect the important characters but I say there is no need for it. First, linearity sux anyway and you should have the freedom to mess up the story as you want (there should be alternative solutions anyway). Second, coincidentally at these locations are some stashes which must be broken open for items, so you just don't get them. Third, if you happen to wage war with this faction, it sometimes still blocks your weapon, which means you cannot defend yourself. I say no to this kindergarten.the faction war is beside the main quest the only other chain of connected quests. it is advised not to join a faction too early in order not to lose access to some characters, traders and quests. The fight also continues after you completely destroy the enemy as the reinforcements will steadily (and a bit too frequently imo) reconquer their base.after entering limansk you will not be able to go back to explore so save before it. such a shame for a rich open world full of secrets.speaking of secrets: the scavanging and explorative aspect of the game are very interesting but are undermined by the fact that the hidden stashes (except normal stashes) are empty as long as you didn't recover any information about them from an enemy corpse or a broker. thus venturing into dangerous places sometimes has no rewards whatsoever for you if you didn't unlock them.the number of quests, both unique and repeatable are far too low for such a rich universe.just as the number of unique characters or dialogues. unfortunately the number of artifacts is fixed and no new appear. dungeons: basically there is only one dungeon in the game which is really underwhelming. _______________________________________________________-engine: somewhat clumsy and clunky when it comes to object collision. if you have bad luck some items will fall in places where you just cannot pick them... I also enjoyed climbing things like a tree in order to get a secret... NOT. it is also very unhandy that every other person in the game is considered a solid unmovable object for you which can however push you by just walking on you, thus characters sometimes block entrances to buildings etc-graphics: still not bad. surely it's not crysis or something, but still enjoyable.-main story: unfortunately you have no alternative endings and no way to change the main story. the finale is also somewhat unspectacular and boring. the "boss fight" is nothing innovative/not enjoyable. -afterplay: once again you have no ability to discover the world after the main story ends, such a shame for such an open world game. also after entering limansk there is no going back.-bugs: no significant bugs were detected. once the game crashed and the last save file became corrupted, so frequent saving with several alternating files is advised.

												Man i have 200+ hours on the other STALKERs and am a strong supporter of the series, i do have to say this was a bit of a let down, I anticipated it though which is why i bought this last.--------------------------To start off I download complete mod every stalker i buy to rid bugs and such, but even that wasnt enough for this game.I tried sooo hard to like it i really did, but its basically an addon to shadow of chernobyl with a few added locations.First thing i realized was how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ the faction battle feature was done, I just killed like 12 bandits with some stalkers wasnt too difficult had to use a few bandages but thats ab it, then literally 5 minutes later as im on the way to save another group of whiny stalkers asses, i get called back to the camp i just ♥♥♥♥ing ridded of bandits, and this happened alot until i left the swamp area its rather annoying especially when all i had was a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ shotgun and a broken AK.This only escalated as i got to the next area ''the cordon'' the starting area from the first game, as i was assuming it looked the exact same but with military running around the whole ♥♥♥♥ing place. Military is the 2nd hardest faction in ALL stalker games next to monolith, and they got me out here fighting 16 of these ♥♥♥♥ers not including the dickwads thatll show up after i leave. It wouldnt be so bad if i didnt have to fight them so early, and maybe if they didnt eat more rounds then the player and have godlike aim 24/7. I mean even the other stalkers got ♥♥♥♥ed, they on the radio calling for help and 10 seconds later they are begging me to hurry up because they have two men left, obviously by the time im there all my stalker buddies are dead besides maybe one guy on the floor begging for me to end his misery, And i cant even help him because they managed to take out 1/16 hostiles, so i mean obviously i left him there.Then after i run away the people on the radio start talking♥♥♥♥♥♥to me for not helping.What happened to yall saying ''Remember stalker dont be a hero'' in the begginning of the game?They should be happy i dont kill them all, because ive used half of my bandages to heal wounds that they caused due to their complete disregard of my life, I mean they look like battle droids in firefights they wont let anything even the mutant horde sneaking up on them stop them from killing the guy who shot them.And the AI straight up will rush your♥♥♥♥♥call of duty style with no regard for there own life breaks the immersion entirely, especially when its military and even when they were dumb for rushing they still penetrate you in your no no regions.This game has hardly any mods to make it a tolerable experience aswell because not alot of mod creators would spend there time saving clear sky.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------Anyways my rant will end here, I will try my hardest to beat the game because the story is the only thing keeping my hope alive at this point, like i said i enjoy the stalker series alot, and i spent my money so i will try to make the best.But please PLEASE dont make this your first STALKER game, sure its cheap, but theres a reason for that.I Would highly recommend you play the other 2 first, before you set your mind on buying this.*Note* Before anyone thinks im being too harsh or i simply suck at the game, ive played both games thoroughly beating them both a few times on different difficulties, i know how to survive the zone.This isnt the zone, this is chernobyl with a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s terrorizing and running amok the place and im supposed to somehow complete the main quest while being called back and fourth between camps. Maybe in 3 years ill rewrite this review when i finally found the button to tell my stalker buddies theyre on their own because im walking around with one ♥♥♥♥ing arm slowly bleeding out with a ♥♥♥♥ing mob of bloodsuckers watching over me waiting for their next meal.

												Im big on Clear Sky as some are critical of it. Dont get it twisted this game is TOUGH AS NAILS, you will die..over and over, not knowing how or why, grenade spam is REAL, Enemies bullets defy gravity and do matrix stuff to find you. If you play on veteran or master then you will break a computer component in frustration. you think dark souls is tough..Souls games cant hold a candle to this game especially. But yet i loved ever tortorous moment because i finished it. Also i havent played Call of Pripyat yet but played and completed Stalker Shadow of Chernobly and loved it..even though i didnt play it till mid 2015. But Clear Sky is every bit of enjoyable with that sense of Immersion that a post apocalyptic game really can give you. Sound effects are gnarly, the added elements and different characters (well not design wise) and there personalities. Dangerous.. check, Immersive.. Check, great visuals with the dynamic lighting (if your rig supports).. Check, sound effects make your skin crawl...Check.All the while if you play the first one you get to revisit these places but the this game clear sky is set a few years before Shadow of Chernobly. Its great to see how the Zone has changed from game to game..remebering where dangerous spots were before might not be there in the other game. Love the Plot that the Zone (which is where the melt down occured) is living and breathing and has its own life force..how theres different factions fighting among each other over beliefs of the Zone, like some want to research it others want to kill everything in it. Hippies peace and love Yin Yang stuff..i finished game in 70 hours..death total...220. its BRUTALGreat game 9/10

content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												Fantastic game! I've been interested in the Chernobyl NPP accident for a while. S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky is the second installment in the franchise. It was released in 2008. The S.T.A.L.K.E.R. franchise is the only game franchise in the world that is about the Chernobyl disaster except for "Chernobyl: Terrorist Attack". The game is about a second explosion at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant (NPP) near Pripyat in Ukraine. The game takes place in 2011. The game has great atmosphere, I don't really think that the graphics are that bad. I think they are good enough. Sure it doesn't look like Battlefield 1 or something but the graphics are a part of the experience! It's really challenging and the way you walk around alone out in the dark at night is terrifying, you feel like someone is going to sneak up on you and kill you. Weapons are pretty much the same as the other S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games, but they are kinda unique. NPCs are great, sometimes they might not react to get shot at but they are mostly good. The mutants are powerful and scary. Enviroment is very detailed and it's beautiful for being a nuclear exclusion zone. It's dark and scary. Love it! You should definetly get it!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												Clear Sky is considered the red headed step child of the STALKER franchise, but in all honesty it's my favorite of the 3 STALKER games and I will explain why to you.Clear Sky (CS) revamped a lot of the clunky design that was present in Shadow of Chernobyl (SoC), and paved the way for a lot of the useful features that were present in Call of Pripyat (CoP).  First off, CS overhauled your PDA immensely, cutting out a lot of the unnecessary features and streamlining your available options.Artifacts also received a major makeover in the game in how you acquire them, and their overall functionality.  Thanks to CS, artifact hunting means you have to actually "hunt".  In STALKER's predecessor, artifacts could be found just laying on the ground and were in a huge abundance.  In CS, you actually have to jump into anomalies with a special detector to find the goodies inside.  And the goodies are actually worth it as well.  An artifact that increases your endurance (recovery speed from jumping, running etc.) has a more limited value than in SoC, prompting you to equip more than one if you're going out on a long raid.  On the up side, health restoring artifacts have a major impact on keeping you alive and actually heal you faster than they do in CoP.  If I had to take a guess, I'd say that little feature has a lot to do with your character's "gift", but you'll figure out what that means when you play it.The world feels more alive, with many of the NPCs getting unique voice actors, as well as a lot of them also interacting with each other.  You can really get a feel for this when you get to Freedom's base and meet the two stalkers that keep hijacking the outpost's loudspeaker to talk smack to each other.  Plus the NPCs are more reactive, they will tell you to buzz off if you're trying to talk to them with a gun in their face, or they'll smack your gun out of your hands if you keep trying to talk to them with it out.  They're also liable to smack you in the face if you keep trying to talk to them while they're in the middle of a firefight or on their way to complete their own objectives.The ALife in this game can be buggy at times, but that's because of the extra features added to the system since SoC.  Enemies can, and will use grenades on you.  And they've all got their own pre-programmed cycles and tactical combat styles.  Some enemies will try to flank you, while others will box you into a tight space with no escape.  Some may charge at you blindly, while others will retreat to call in reinforcements.  A hungry mutant that spots you may follow you throughout the Zone until you either dispatch it, or it dispatches you...while a less hungry mutant may just be protecting its territory and will leave you be once you leave its area.But my favorite thing about the game is how it sets up the story for the STALKER universe.  This game is prequel to Shadow of Chernobyl, and as such it tries to paint a picture of a more beautiful Zone; one that's still bustling with human interaction and chipper attitudes despite the hellish landscape they live in.  SoC is the opposite of this, by the time it takes place the Zone is nearly lifeless and it really makes you feel empty and alone inside.  What makes Clear Sky so great though, is the tragic ending of the game.  SoC has multiple endings, but only two "true" endings...and of those two only one is cannon to the story.  But it's a happy ending overall.  In Clear Sky you don't get such a happy ending because it has to show you why the Zone is such a nightmare in the future to come.In closing, Clear Sky gets a lot of flak for being the weakest of the 3 games.  But it is not a weak game, not by a long shot.  GSC Gameworld took some risks when they introduced Clear Sky because it changed the mold that Shadow of Chernobyl had set after so many years of being in development.  Overall, I personally feel like it paid off.  I prefer the way NPCs interact with one another and the game world, I love the rebalancing of artifacts and the methods of hunting them down, and if you can get past the occasional hiccup or two due to shoddy programming...the experience is worth it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												First I want to say that this game is extremely difficult, even on "Stalker" (Normal). Near the end of the game you will not be able to purchase bandages or medkits, and trust me you will need them. If you run out of medkits you will have to turtle your way through massive and very cheap spawning enemies. Now I don't think this is a bad game, if it was intended to be hard then they nailed it. The problems I have with it are such:-Enemies have a hitbox inefficiency, some enemies take massive amounts of ammo (1-2 clips) and others take a few shots even if they are the same. Don't bother aiming for the head it works on the lesser enemies.-The game goes from a really decent RPG to a linear shooting gallery where you hind behind numerous walls and crates with a "hold" crouch which does not fit well. -The ending of the game is something that unless you find out ahead of time you will never beat it. Unless you see that you need ungodly amounts of medkits and bandages "YOU WILL NOT WIN".-There are bugs yes but sometimes freaking out and hitting the move keys enough you can get out. If not you better have saved recently. -Autosaves are only when you go to new areas, other than that if you don't save you will be playing this game a very long time.-Gun upgrading is expensive for the lack of money you normally have. Plus the weapon will lower in condition very quickly so money in this game is your best friend.-Finally, the money, if you don't farm and chore through the swamps and all the anomalies to find artifaces or pick up every gun you see, you will have "NO" money. Other than these things I find that it is weirdly addicting and quite fun and funny sometimes. If you like really hard games well this game is great.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												So Ive played about 9.1 hoursThis contains minor spoilers possibly.*************************Vanilla game-no mods whatsoever*************************************Im where I need to get the documents for that science dude. Ive joined freedom and took the base (which they recaptured 10 minutes later but whatever).I am good on money and got the Vintar and Veles from the Swamp. I use the Skat-9, Ak74, PKM, and have many meds. No artifacts. I sold them for upgrade. I think this is enough background info.I am enjoying this game but it is, for sure, the weakest link in the series. I started with CoP, then SoC, now this. I came with little expectations with all the crap I heard about bugs. To be honest I havent seen to many. When I tried to change my settings it crashed. Solution? Dont change every single thing at once. Worked for me.When I caught a place for Clear Sky, I had to hold the point but it didnt do anything. Solution? Do F5 then F9 (quicksave/reload). That solved it. There are probably other bugs in the Factions War stuff but I havent seen them. Other than that settings change crash it hasnt crashed once. This is actually less then SoC (which was also played vanilla only).After coming from SoC I do like the mods and repair. Its just a shame this wasnt optimized/done better as it could have been the best in the series. Seems to be bigger world than CoP with all the mods and repair!Others dont like they reused areas from SoC, but it IS half the price for a reason. I actually like it too. I feel like Im exploring my (as in strelok's) past going through it.The story? I like it. But I liked all of them. I think they tie in nice. (Its all really about Strelok to a point)I give it a 7.5/10  -  If you love S.T.A.L.K.E.R. then you should at the very least give it a chance. Im glad I did.*It does feel a little less STALKER-y but its still fine. I can explain the less mutants since, you know, the Zone is younger and such. Hasnt expanded as far.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2016
												Another story of Stalker universe. It's before the Shadows of Charnobyl. A group of stalkers has for the first time reached the very heart of the Zone, Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant. An immense blow out of anomalous energy changes the Zone. Stalkers and even expeditions die or end up sealed on the lost territories. New areas, which remained unknown since the zone in Shadows of Charnobyl, appear on the map. You must look out on blowouts what can kill you. The anomalous activity is at its maximum. Changes of the Zone map known to stalkers shake the fragile balance of forces in the Zone. Among the groupings, there flare up hostilities for the new territories and artefact fields. There are no more old enemies or friends. The Factions War has started between the groupings and you are who will choice, who you join in it.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
Plot SummaryClear Sky happens at the sametime as Shadow of Chernobyl story event progresses. But the ending would leave its player to judge which side really happened based on their cinematics. In a form of major backtrack up the memory lane, but players still get new areas. 3/7/2016Contents compared to previousThe game presents a harsher UI interface, new detector features, with new deadly anomalies, weapon upgrades, more artifacts.Having previously played Master on SoC and then Stalker difficulty on Clear Sky, I happened to die more often on this one probably cause I rushed hard with my starting vest and hardly any artifacts worth carrying, and being quite certain enemies also have their own [new] combat contents, I would assume Clear Sky is an additional story the developers made to seek improvement changes from its previous series and possibly turned it better (As it did on its next series)Notable gameplay aspects:-fail covers/barricades, or npc just knew where to shoot through walls..+fast backtrack travel access after reaching a certain progression+better graphic (inc. Day, night and weather system)+grenades shower~harder enemies/stronger AI mechanism (stronger aimbot lolz)+better quest objectives, still time-framed+less RU rewards+harder-earned gears-punishing for slow-learners+derpazz Friendly npcand I'd conclude that artifacts is EVERYTHING in this game if anyone wants to strive easy at, the access for them is just hard as the game encourage alot of exploration to locate them with your detector.if pros and cons assumed balanced for your thoughts, and that you're hardcore at most fps, this is a recommend for its difficulty, I'm not sure about the contrary though...Review8/10 would get stuck in a pit of rocks in the middle of the dark night again.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												Stalker Clear Sky, like its predecessor Shadow of Chernobyl, is a post-apocalyptic survival-horror shooter taking place in the Zone of Exclusion around Chernobyl. Now, unlike its predecessor, Clear Sky has added certain new features that enhance the gameplay, such as the Factions War. In the game, multiple factions are vying for control of the Zone, and your character can join a group and help them secure the Zone, bringing in wealth, but also making new enemies, so choose wisely. Furthermore, the ability to repair and upgrade weapons and armor is now available to the player, allowing you to alter your equipment to best suit your play style. However, the story is quite frankly not as good as Shadow of Chernobyls, in my opinion. It lacks the intensity and depth that Shadow of Chernobyl has. I played this game with the Clear Sky Complete mod, which again fixes numerous bugs and noticeably improves graphics. All that in mind, this is a fantastic shooter, with several new features that set it apart from the original, although it doesn't quite measure up to the original in terms of atmosphere and story. Overall Score: 9.5/10

Can you make it to the Center and Stop whatever is going on?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 6, 2013
												"STALKER: Clear Sky" is a good prequal to the 2007 title "STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl". "Good", not "great". While its strongest point is its plot (i.e., its part in the series), some areas of game felt a bit rushed.You play as Scar, a mercenary whose exposure to the zone has caused his nervous system to start shutting down. Sorta. Each new emission is a tick on the countdown for him, but in the meantime he's hardened against some of the Zone's ill effects.It's a good plotline, but the game has a different feel to it compared to the previous game.Where SoC ("Shadow of Chernobyl") only emphasized factions as a plot device, CS makes them a central issue. At least, it often feels that way. Each map provides an overhead of the sparring factions, your relationship with each faction, and an overview of controlled territories. Your first mission is basically a tutorial on applying this information.And zone "emissions" -- though not yet as important or troubling as in the third game ("STALKER: Call of Pripyat") -- are suddenly part of the environment, having seemingly been cut from the first game. No hidden endings this time... because you should already know how it ends. As often happens with sequels, the final mission is action-oriented but feels very contrived. The ending movie provides great continuity with the first game's footage, solidifying "Clear Sky"'s place in the trilogy.But don't stop now -- the best game is next.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 2
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Clear Sky is second installment of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series and is a prequel to the first game Shadow of Chernobyl.Game is set in Chernobyl zone five years after second Chernobyl disaster. Player is given control of Scar, a mercenary who is employed by Clear Sky faction to go after a group of stalkers trying to breach the center of the zone.Since Shadow of Chernobyl, this game offers interesting addition of faction wars system. Different factions struggle for territory, either attacking other faction for territory gain or defending one already owned.Game also include new system of weapon customization with the ability to repair gear and add new modifications to it. New system of anomalies, which are harder to notice and one can obtain artifacts only by using special detector.NPC's AI also improved since first game, making fight's harder, more dynamic and more interesting.Although much improvement has been made, this game is not superior to it's predecessor. Throughout the game I have found many bugs which forced me to load previous saves so I could progress in story. But most disappointing thing for me was ending. I'm not going to spill any detail but for me it was like developers wanted to hasten it and it lost part of immersion.In any case I still recommend this game. I really liked the improvements and various mods that can enhance gaming experience even better.

Worth a buy for sure, especially if you like wasteland-style games but think Fallout 4 is too casual.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 31
												It’s not as good as Shadow of Chornobyl, this game feels very experimental. It feels like the developers had a lot of small new ideas and tweaks to the gameplay they wanted to add to the second installment of the franchise and these changes overall made the game less enjoyable than the first game. It’s also buggier and less polished than the original, they probably didn’t have enough time to iron out the issues the game had. The final boss of the game is very buggy because the boss can easily fall through the floor if you load after you die or he could be invincible while floating in the air etc. I actually managed to make him glitch out to my benefit at the start of the fight by quick saving and quick loading while he is climbing down a ladder, when I quick loaded it made him climb back up the ladder to reset the animation of him going down the ladder which allowed me to easily beat him.  The story is very simple compared to the first game, it mostly consists of you tracking down the protagonist of the first game to kill him before he reaches the center of the zone and you can predict exactly what will happen very early on because this is a prequel story and takes place 1 year before Shadow of Chernobyl. It was cool to see how different the world was in that one year gap and knowing how things will change in the future. Clear Sky is much more difficult than the first game on master difficulty, it feels like they heavily increased the enemy’s accuracy on master and there is just a lot of inconsistency in the firefights themselves. It becomes absurd at some points like when I barely even peeked out of cover and I got killed in one hit when I was full hp. A lot of things like that happen pretty often which forces you to quick save very frequently. The developers also had the brilliant idea of letting the enemy throw grenades that land perfectly next to your feet every time they do throw them. All these things combined make the gunplay of Clear Sky much more frustrating and less fun and immersive than Shadow of Chornobyl because those issues constantly bring you out of the game. The great atmosphere is still there and visiting the new locations they added was cool. It’s still a good game it’s just not great like the first game was. 7/10 (Good)

content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												The one thing I've noticed about the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series is how it always maintains it's appeal through simple-seeming tasks that always branch off into multiple quests and missions. This game also does just that. It is immersive in the sense that every character has a story, be it simple or not and that the horror situations generally aren't planned like they are in most other games. They are purely situational. Unlike CoP, this game doesn't necessarily have as much of a large focus on survival insomuch as it does on killing the enemy; that could be taken positively or negatively depending on what genres of games you like. Either way though, this game appeals to multiple aspects of different genres which I feel is why it such a good game. Also, "ANUUU CHEEKI BREEKI I V DAMKE!!!!" *cheeki breeki hardbass intensifies*
